title.value: Homotopic local-global parcellation of the human cerebral cortex from resting-state functional connectivity
title.justification: The title clearly indicates the focus of the paper on homotopic local-global parcellation of the human cerebral cortex using resting-state functional connectivity.
title.quote: Homotopic local-global parcellation of the human cerebral cortex from resting-state functional connectivity

extractions.description: This paper discusses the extension of a previously developed model to derive homotopic areal-level parcellations of the human cerebral cortex using resting-state functional connectivity. These homotopic parcellations maintain homogeneity and correlate with brain lateralization, providing a neurobiologically meaningful subdivision of the cortex.

type.justification: The paper presents empirical results from applying a new model to derive homotopic areal-level parcellations and compares these with several existing parcellations.
type.quote: Using resting-fMRI and task-fMRI across diverse scanners, acquisition protocols, preprocessing and demographics, we show that the resulting homotopic parcellations are as homogeneous as the Schaefer parcellations, while being more homogeneous than five publicly available parcellations.

name.justification: The primary research field is neuroscience, as the study focuses on brain parcellation and connectivity.
name.quote: Resting-state fMRI is commonly used to derive brain parcellations, which are widely used for dimensionality reduction and interpreting human neuroscience studies.

name.justification: The paper leverages resting-state functional connectivity to perform cerebral parcellation, making it a subfield focus.
name.quote: Homotopic local-global parcellation of the human cerebral cortex from resting-state functional connectivity.

name.justification: The study involves the parcellation of the human cerebral cortex, explicitly mentioned in the paper's goals.
name.quote: a model that integrates local and global approaches for estimating areal-level cortical parcellations.

name.justification: The hMRF model is the primary model proposed and utilized in the paper for homotopic parcellation of the cerebral cortex.
name.quote: Our proposed hMRF objective function has a fourth homotopic constraint term that encourages homotopic pairs of vertices to be assigned to homotopic pairs of parcels.

is_contributed.justification: The paper introduces the hMRF model as a contribution to achieve homotopic parcellations.
is_contributed.quote: we extend the gwMRF model to derive homotopic areal-level parcellations.

is_executed.justification: The hMRF model was executed to derive parcellations, as discussed in the methodology and results sections.
is_executed.quote: A homotopic Markov Random Field (hMRF) parcellation procedure was developed and applied to resting-fMRI...

is_compared.justification: The hMRF model's results are compared with several other existing parcellations.
is_compared.quote: We compared the hMRF parcellations with six publicly available parcellations...

referenced_paper_title.value: Local-global parcellation of the human cerebral cortex from intrinsic functional connectivity MRI
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper mentions extending the gwMRF model, which was discussed in the previous work on local-global parcellation.

name.justification: The GSP dataset is explicitly mentioned as the primary dataset used for deriving the hMRF parcellations.
name.quote: A homotopic Markov Random Field (hMRF) parcellation procedure was developed and applied to resting-fMRI from the GSP dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Brain genomics superstruct project initial data release with structural, functional, and behavioral measures
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references the GSP dataset, aligning with the broader Brain Genomics Superstruct Project.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The GSP dataset consisted of resting-fMRI data from 1489 young adults aged between 18 to 35 years old (Holmes et al., 2015).

name.justification: The HCP dataset is used for evaluation in the study, making it an essential part of the research.
name.quote: For the purpose of evaluation, we considered resting-fMRI data from the HCP S1200 release.

referenced_paper_title.value: The Human Connectome Project: a data acquisition perspective
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper mentions using the HCP dataset, which is part of the Human Connectome Project, for evaluation purposes.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Human Connectome Project: a data acquisition perspective

name.justification: The ABCD dataset is used to evaluate parcellation quality in children.
name.quote: We also considered 9- to 10-year-old children from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) dataset to evaluate parcellation quality in children.

referenced_paper_title.value: The adolescent brain cognitive development (ABCD) study: imaging acquisition across 21 sites
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper uses the ABCD dataset, as described in The adolescent brain cognitive development study, to evaluate model performance.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Details of the ABCD dataset can be found elsewhere (Casey et al., 2018).

name.justification: The GUSTO dataset is used to evaluate generalization across different ethnic groups.
name.quote: we also considered resting-fMRI data from 7.5-year-old children in the Growing Up in Singapore Towards Healthy Outcomes (GUSTO) dataset.

aliases: Growing Up in Singapore Towards Healthy Outcomes

referenced_paper_title.value: Cohort Profile: Growing Up in Singapore Towards healthy Outcomes (GUSTO) birth cohort study
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references the GUSTO dataset as detailed in the cohort profile.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Details of the GUSTO dataset can be found elsewhere (Soh et al., 2014).

name.justification: FreeSurfer is specifically mentioned as part of the fMRI processing pipeline in the study.
name.quote: Detailed information about the resting-fMRI preprocessing can be found elsewhere (Li et al., 2019 ). Here we provide the broad outlines of the processing steps, which utilized a mixture of FreeSurfer 5.3.0 ( Fischl, 2012 ), FSL 5.0.8 ( Jenkinson et al., 2012 ) and in-house Matlab functions.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to FreeSurfer software is cited directly, indicating its use.

name.justification: FSL is explicitly mentioned as part of the fMRI preprocessing in conjunction with FreeSurfer.
name.quote: Detailed information about the resting-fMRI preprocessing can be found elsewhere (Li et al., 2019 ). Here we provide the broad outlines of the processing steps, which utilized a mixture of FreeSurfer 5.3.0 ( Fischl, 2012 ), FSL 5.0.8 ( Jenkinson et al., 2012 ) and in-house Matlab functions.

referenced_paper_title.justification: FSL software reference indicates its employment in the context of this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Jenkinson, M., Beckmann, C.F., Behrens, T.E.J., Woolrich, M.W., Smith, S.M., 2012. FSL. NeuroImage, 20 YEARS OF fMRI 62, 782–790.
